I'm glad I rediscovered it, and I'll surely be back!

1.description: Mity Nice was a disappointment yesterday.  I have frequented Mity Nice many times and it has always been a solid place to eat.  I don't know if yesterday was an off day for them or if the quality is just simply going down.I made a reservation for my boyfriend and me.  Even though I had a reservation, we couldn't get a table for about 15 minutes.  When we sat down, the space in the booth was very cramped.  I think they reconfigured the seating so that they could fit in more tables.Needless to say, it wasn't comfortable.Next, the service was SLOW.  It took 20 minutes to get drinks and from the time that we sat down until we were served our dinner, it was 35 minutes.  We had to ask to get our water glasses filled.  I needed to ask for another glass of wine.  Service was not attentive.Now for the food.  It was just OK.  My prime rib special was not great.   The meat was dry and WAY overcooked.  I asked for medium and received dry and well done.  My boyfriend said his Thanksgiving dinner was good but the vegetables and potatoes were on the cold side.I used to frequently go to Mity Nice but I was so disappointed that I don't think I will be going back for some time.

55.description: Great place tucked away from all the noise of the food court. The salads were amazing. My wife and I split the Acapulco salad and chopped rotisserie chicken salad. Plus the draft IPA was local and awesome. We'll be back on our next trip.

9.description: Love the cheese rolls, deviled eggs, fish & chils, and the French onion soup. These are some of my go to meals when I choose MNG. Should have gone with one of my tried and trues. Went out on a limb today and ordered the chicken and waffles. Waffles were delicious. Chicken was tender but breaded with something that made it too spicy for my taste. For $15, I was given a generous portion and ended up taking 2:3 pieces home where I took off the breading and enjoyed more than the original meal. Any of the wait staff you get here are super friendly!

26.description: Great meal, great service!  I saw this place on yelp and it was close to my hotel. I had my doubts since it was in the mall, but it was amazing!  You get a nice basket of warm cheese popovers when you sit down. I would have been happy with just those and my delicious Honey Paloma! My server Justin was super friendly and spot on with his recommendation for the tuna tacos. These are the put-your-own-together kind of tacos- perfectly seared tuna, fresh corn tortillas, yummy guacamole with a nice light cabbage jalapeño slaw on the side. Cotija cheese and salsa too.   Skip the Cheesecake Factory and overpriced food at the hotels. This place is really good!

25.description: Mity Nice Grill was mity nice!! I had been here once a long time ago and barely remember my experience in detail. However, I remember it being pretty good and family friendly. We had a reservation at Girl and a Goat for that evening. Not sure why, though I waited for months for a reservation there, each time I had to cancel. Our party grew and now it involved two toddlers and we decided to switch venue. I suggested Mity Nice Grill and everyone agreed.We were a little late due to traffic from Shedd Aquarium, but they were very accommodating with our reservation. No problem at all. When we got there, our table was set up with two high chairs and we were greeted right away with some cheesy poofs. It was like a mini popover but very cheesy. It was good. The table gobbled them up in no time!We ordered guacamole to start that was great! They're garlicky, fresh, and had a little kick. Too bad the kids who usually liked avocado didn't care for it because it was a little spicy. The adults loved it though. My sister who loves root beer was so impressed they had a whole root beer menu along with alcoholic root beer.My mom who loves French Onion soup boasted that it was best she had. It was pretty damn good I had to agree. It was soo cheesy and the soup itself was sweet from onion and not salty like it usually is. The chicken and kale soup was also delicious and light. Everyone seemed to enjoy their entrees. At first, we all wanted the fish special or the white fish in lemon butter sauce. However, most of us changed our mind since we just got back from Shedd Aquarium and didn't have the heart to eat fish after looking at how they were swimming around totally alive in aquariums. Except, my heartless sister. My sister went with the fish special and loved it. I went with the terri d chicken that was so good and sister in law enjoyed her filet mignon pot roast. The kids had some mac and cheese that was pretty good as well.Desserts.. The cookie skillet and the blueberry crostada were great! Yumm!! Overall, the food was great!It was no surprise. We can always count on a Lettuce restaurant. Though not fancy and overly gourmet, it was a great family meal. Plus, prices were very reasonable. We also thought the dad from Family Ties was eating with his family on the table next to us. It was a mity nice meal. Parking can be validated if you parked at Water Tower with a minimum purchase of $10. A couple of low notes, refills were slow and they didn't give us clean silverware for desserts. However, everything else was awesome.

12.description: Deviled eggs were delicious. Other than that everything else I had from the menu was mediocre. I had a chicken salad, coffee and dessert and all 3 even the coffee were not worth the price. Thank heaven for those deviled eggs otherwise I would've been completely robbed.

59.description: It was a surprise when we found pizza of this quality in such a location. You would be hard pressed to find anything better, even in downtown Chicago! We didn't try the deep dish, but it looked amazing. The thin crust was superb.

21.description: I've been back for dinner now and I must say that Mity Nice has, again, exceeded my expectations. My wife got the skirt steak (which was all kinds of fabulous - I will get it next time) and I got the Pot Roast "Filet Mignon," which was truly amazing, though a touch fatty. My recommendation would be to braise it about 30 minutes more, but the flavor was well worth twice the price. A highlight was my dessert: a salted caramel root beer float! In all seriousness, if you haven't been here, give it a shot. Multiple root beer selections, comfort food & great service... What's not to love? Fast becoming my "go to" place on the Mag Mile.

17.description: We were on our way to see a play when we decided to Have a drink,  we were pointed back to mity nice and although we had a poor experience our first time we didn't think just drinks will hurt.  We walked in at 630. March 8thSat at the bar.  We ordered 2 Margaritas one subbed with vodka,  and deviled eggs. When we received our food we were not offered plates napkins or flatware. We literally ate with our bare hands and no napkins. The bar seemed to have a lot of tickets. So we snatched our own napkin.Our drinks came. We got a vodka margarita and a cranberry crush. :/As she gave us our drinks she realized that wasn't what we ordered. I don't know.  I guess that's the end of the review.

10.description: Some friends and I came here for dinner one evening and had an enjoyable meal.Décor: It is a pretty nice place, more upscale than your average chain restaurant but not as nice as a "fancy" place. However, I would feel a bit uncomfortable just rolling in wearing a t-shirt and jeans. That being said, it is very casual and relaxed, which is nice. The lighting is a tad bit dimmed to help set the relaxed atmosphere and the music reinforces everything. There are plenty of tables but this place is quite popular so you may have to wait.Bathroom: nice and clean and inviting.Staff: Our waiter was pretty cool. He seemed to be very busy and have a lot of tables, perhaps someone did not show up for their shift, but he didn't let it show at all when he interacted with us. Food: We started with these little bread things that were delicious, I had some bourbon (a decent pour) and then moved on to our main courses. We had a few different items ranging from: a burger to the pot roast to the salmon. Everything was well prepared, served hot, and tasted fresh. The portion sizes are pretty sizable as well, which is very nice. For drinks we sampled some of their rootbeer and it was very tasty!Value: Given the décor, the portion sizes, and the food quality (let's not forget service) I'd say you get your money's worth here.I really enjoyed our meal and would consider returning if I am again in the area.

5.description: First time there and really enjoyed myself. Awesome burgers! the vanilla root beer was very good and the server was very polite, she explained the menu and was attentive to our needs. Looking forward to going back again soon!

3.description: The only negative thing about this restaurant is that you have to pass through the crowded food court to get to it. Which is why a lot of visitors to Water Tower Place never realize it's here. Too bad, as it really is the hidden treasure in a sea of over-priced food court food.  When I lived down the street, I came here a lot. Now that it's more of a trek, I visit whenever I'm shopping nearby or have tickets to Lookingglass Theatre. Recently dined here with a friend and was glad to see it's as good as ever. The décor had been updated, and there were a lot of new items on the menu, but thankfully my old favorites were still offered. And the service, as always, was excellent.We started with martinis and a basket of their signature popovers... so good we asked for a second basket.  I had a cup of my favorite French onion soup, slightly sweet onions in a flavorful broth topped with three different melted cheeses.  Followed it with the Acapulco salad, fresh ingredients tossed with lime cilantro dressing, which was just tart enough. My friend, who loves comfort food, had the meatloaf with mashed potatoes. He pronounced it a winner. (Mity Nice served comfort food years before it became popular.) Hated to pass up desert (a trade-off with the popovers), but enjoyed several cups of coffee and never felt rushed. I really do miss the convenience of living close by.

35.description: Every time I come to Chicago I have to make a stop at this place.  I have dreams about the Acapulco salad and those popovers in between my visits.  The location is very random, and it's definitely confusing to get in to.  But if you can find it, it is definitely worth a try.  Also had the sweet potato fries, french onion soup, and chips and guacamole on this visit; all were delicious!

19.description: The food here is great. My stomach was upset so I didn't get anything fancy but the Mac and cheese was fantastic. My sister got a burger which was great. Elise was an amazing server even though it looked like she was bartender. Highly recommend. My sister is gluten free and they had a good gluten menu choice and she didn't get sick after so it was actually gluten free. Hip place as well.

28.description: We stopped in here for a Saturday afternoon snack. Finding this place inside the madness that is the Water Tower building was rather challenging. There is a crazy food buffet thingy in front of Mity Nice that will throw you off, but once you find the restaurant all will be well. We split some guac and had a cocktail (good) and some craft root beer (great!). We'll be back.

45.description: Meatloaf was very good!  Quick service others in my group had the turkey dinner and the pot roast all very good.   Didn't realize it was inside of a mall.

33.description: Not the easiest place to find, but my girlfriend and I enjoyed this place a lot. We ordered relatively commonplace menu items that we've each eaten hundreds of times elsewhere, e.g. Mac and cheese, burgers, fries, but we were nonetheless greatly pleased.

43.description: This is an excellent option for gluten free and allergy friendly meals. Albeit hard to find, they were incredibly accommodating of my gluten free and low FODMAP diet. If you are dining there and have food allergies ask for Martine. He was amazing.

2.description: We won $100 in gift certificates in a raffle and went here for dinner after work on a Monday.  That is a good day because wine is $5 a glass. I had two of the "not your dad's" root beers. They are sweet (but good) so switched to wine after that.  My wife ordered a blueberry pomegranate lemon drop, which tasted weak. I ordered the crispy fish sandwich and the wife ordered bacon cheeseburger. Both were good. This is essentially bar food, but it's good bar food. We have $25 left on gift certificate so will be back.  The server was friendly and attentive.  At least on a Monday, this was not a young person's bar. At 42 and 42, the wife and I were among the youngest patrons.

18.description: We came in for an early lunch/late brunch planning to do some shopping damage on Michigan Ave after eating. At 11:30 AM, the place was pretty empty despite the area teeming with tourists on the holiday weekend. I ordered the Apple Cinnamon French Toast, not really knowing what that would be. It turns out to be almost identical to the Cinnamon Apple Pancake for the Original Pancake House. Except it is about 2/3 the size and 2/3 the cost. That really isn't a criticism. I LOVE the Cinnamon Apple Pancake at Original Pancake House, and I absolutely loved this dish as well - but it really wasn't what I expected for French Toast. It has the advantage over the Pancake House  version in that it is a more manageable size (the Original Pancake House version is really a meal for 2 very hungry people - this can be eaten by one with only moderate amount of guilt for overeating). My wife had the Chopped Chicken Salad which she said was terrific - also a huge portion. As a pass out before the meal, they gave gluten free pop overs that were very tasty. Overall, excellent food, excellent service, excellent ambiance. A definite 5 star rating.

41.description: Came in with a 12pm reservation on Saturday and the place was pretty empty but it was packed when we left. Our sever was very kind and friendly. The menu has changed since the last time I was in, but I got the club sandwich and it was very good and quite large. Guacamole appetizer was good as well. My brother loved his grilled cheese and my mom enjoyed her fish tacos. Always a fun stop!

52.description: Really good service. The food was excellent. Had Lime Chicken Tacos and Tuna Tacos for lunch. I definitely recommend this place.

50.description: Tucked away in the mall, thus is a tasty gem. We stopped in for lunch and sat at the bar. Everyone was friendly, great service. We each had a couple beers, not a huge draft selection, but some nice local micro brews which is nice especially when you're an out of towner. We received the delicious, melt-in-your-mouth cheesy bread bites that the serve, and feel in love! They are light, airy, perfectly crispy and cheesy and melty. For lunch I tried the Elvis Burger, which has peanut butter, crispy bacon, cheddar cheese on a pretzel bun. I was intrigued and not disappointed. The flavor was amazing. My boyfriend ordered the tuna tacos, which arrived seared to perfection. Our bartender brought me a side of the chipotle sauce they have, and said it was great with the sweet potato fries. She was not lieing, that sauce was amazing. He putt a little on the tacos as well, that was an excellent addition she brought out for us. Great restaurant!

4.description: By being part of the Lettuce Entertain You rewards program, I got suckered into going to one of their restaurant since they mailed me a big booklet of restaurant coupons that you can scratch off to reveal the coupon amount. Ugh, they know my weak spot.So, how did we end up at Mity Nice Bar & Grill? Here's a recap of my conversation with my friend:Me: Let's do Beatrix. It's a 5-min walk from your office.*Browsing through the menu and Yelp reviews*(30 minutes later..........)Friend: I JUST had lunch at Beatrix lol.Me: NoOoOoOoOoo. I'm guessing you don't want to go back there huh? Lol.Friend: Yeah, probably not.Me: What about Ramen-San?*About to browse through the Ramen-San menu*(5 minutes later..........)Friend: Uhhh no ramen :( Sry lol.Me: What about Wildfire? It's right there by your work. It's actually in the same building as your work.*Browses through Wildfire menu and Yelp reviews*(10 minutes later..........)Friend: Omg I feel so bad but I hate wildfire :(Me: LOL. I hate you. ;( What about Mity Nice?Friend: Sure. 6:30pm?..........FINALLY. -___-This restaurant seems like a great lunch and dinner spot with friends or colleagues. There are booths along the wall, tables in the middle, and a bar on one side of the restaurant. We were seated immediately upon arrival at a table.The cheese rolls were amazing. Despite being lactose intolerant, I made an exception for them. We ordered the green chili chicken nachos and chili-lime chicken tacos. I was not a fan of the chicken nachos because it was covered in cheese, but my friend liked it. The chili-lime chicken tacos were tasty, but it came with cheese on the plate (which was not mentioned on the menu).The service was decent. The server was nice and checked on us just enough times to make sure we were doing okay but not to the point of being overbearing.I think this place is worth checking out once, but I probably won't be a regular without my Lettuce Entertain You coupon since it didn't blow me away.

6.description: I've eaten at Mighty Nice several times and the food, ambience, and service are consistently good. The fish and chips are delicious and the burgers are juicy and fresh. It's simple American bistro fare done very well. It certainly deserves your attention if you're at Water Tower and find yourself in need of a relaxed meal.

22.description: The salads are literally a meal. The burgers are cooked to perfection. And the cheese rolls are legit.Try the root beer Cuz 'Murica.

15.description: Having a real dine in restaurant at the every back of a "cafeteria" was odd for us, we had our doubts. However, the food was surprisingly good. As our waitress addressed their food "comfort food with a twist" they deliver! We started with a Mac and cheese order, absolutely worth every calorie, and there were plenty of them. Then got their veggie burger, fish taco, and chicken something. According to every one, the orders were flavorful and satisfying. Although, the serves were nice, it did not live up to the restaurant atmosphere and level. Plus, the location takes away from it as well, I can describe it as "funny" location. Doubt going back there when ever I visit Chicago!

57.description: My fiancé and I came here for dinner on a Saturday night, and it was fantastic! The atmosphere was calm and had an upscale feel to it. It was a little strange that it was in the middle of a food court, but once we were inside the restaurant we completely forgot that we were in a food court. The service was friendly and fast, but not too fast to where we felt rushed to get out. I ordered a cranberry crush to drink, and I have to say that it was quite possibly the best cocktail I've ordered in a cranberry crush and I have to say it was one of the best cocktails I've had at a restaurant. The vodka wasn't too strong, and it had an amazing ginger flavor. Plus they served it in a mason jar (generous portion)! We had the hummus for an appetizer, which was ok, I probably wouldn't order it again. I had the skirt steak for an entree, which was amazing!! The flavors were perfect and it came with mashed potatoes which were fantastic--clearly made fresh! My fiancé ordered the chicken tacos, which were delicious, but the portion was a little on the small side. For dessert we had the peanut butter Oreo pie thing, which was creamy and delicious!Long story short we would definitely come back next time we're in the area!

20.description: Some friends and I came here for dinner one evening and had an enjoyable meal.Décor: It is a pretty nice place, more upscale than your average chain restaurant but not as nice as a "fancy" place. However, I would feel a bit uncomfortable just rolling in wearing a t-shirt and jeans. That being said, it is very casual and relaxed, which is nice. The lighting is a tad bit dimmed to help set the relaxed atmosphere and the music reinforces everything. There are plenty of tables but this place is quite popular so you may have to wait.Bathroom: nice and clean and inviting.Staff: Our waiter was pretty cool. He seemed to be very busy and have a lot of tables, perhaps someone did not show up for their shift, but he didn't let it show at all when he interacted with us. Food: We started with these little bread things that were delicious, I had some bourbon (a decent pour) and then moved on to our main courses. We had a few different items ranging from: a burger to the pot roast to the salmon. Everything was well prepared, served hot, and tasted fresh. The portion sizes are pretty sizable as well, which is very nice. For drinks we sampled some of their rootbeer and it was very tasty!Value: Given the décor, the portion sizes, and the food quality (let's not forget service) I'd say you get your money's worth here.I really enjoyed our meal and would consider returning if I am again in the area.

36.description: The service is pretty good!! I love the deco in the restaurant! Root beer rocks! The Acapulco Salad is amazing!! Baka tuna tacos are also amazing! The tuna was half done with the freshness of a pink color in the middle and it tastes so tender:)) love this place!!! And the free cheese puffs???!!!! Uhmmmm:))

14.description: The daily special on a Sunday was friend chicken. It was amazingly good and HUGE portions. We started out with the mac n cheese which was the best! My partner in crime had the pot roast wth roasted veggies. Everything we got was delicious and hot! Best comfort food place to dine!

12.description: Boo hiss on Hanig's customer service. I was in last weekend and while they were busy, there were also 2 or 3 workers milling around the cash register at any given moment, and not one person even glanced at me or said "1 sec". It's a shame b/c I typically have good experience with Hanig's. On top of this, I wanted to try on vibram's and barefoot shoes and there were four or five other people trying them on at the same time. In my experience, having multiple customers trying on the same product is easier than running in five different directions.While they are expensive, they have the selection I like.Very disappointed!

7.description: I finally bit the bullet and decided that--fashion be damned!!--I want to train with Vibram five-fingers. But at first I really wanted to try them on and figure out if they would work for me. Enter Hanig's. A quick search of Yelp told me they offer a wide array of Vibrams. Came in on a Saturday around 1pm, and was promptly greeted by a salesman. When I told him what I was looking for, he was incredibly helpful in explaining the different models, especially the ones for running. I proceeded to try on just about every model in the store, and he stuck faithfully by me while I hemmed and hawed over which ones to get. (Indecision is my middle name). I appreciated the no-pressure sales and relaxed atmosphere. They let me run around in the tower to get a feel for the shoes, and while I took a long time to finally purchase, I never got an whiff of impatience.  The other salesman helped out as well, as they all seemed to own a pair, so they let me know which models they wear (and for what activities). The price for the Vibrams is on par which what you find from other retailers, the Vibram website, and even Amazon. Score.So thanks Hanig's--when I need another pair of Vibrams, I'll definitely be back. NOTE: The store is located on the North side of the Hancock building (Delaware street side) at ground level. I wandered around lost for a bit before I found it.

19.description: Very nice sales people. Never felt pressured or obligated to buy. They tend to bend over backwards for you and help you out.

1.description: I've been looking for some comfortable and cute black walking shoes for months. I tried Hanig's on a referral from my mom, who lives in the area. I usually have trouble finding shoes that fit my foot, which is a women's size 11 and pretty wide at the front because of bunions. I had several shoes to choose from in my size, though, and the salesman Walter Perry was very nice and helpful. It was an enjoyable, low pressure shopping experience.

2.description: This was the worst, most hostile, aggressive behavior I have ever experienced from employees in a store.  Two identical pair of shoes got wrinkled linings and inner linings. I owned them less than 6 weeks so I wanted a refund.  Although they offered to repair/replace the linings, I still requested a refund believing the shoes to be constructed from poor materials.When I did not agree to a repair the manager verbally bullied me while two other salesmen stared me down. The manager said they couldn't send the shoes back to the manufacturer. He was so hostile I walked away and sat in one of their chairs to figure out what to do. Then a second staff member approached me and shoved a repair are ticket at me as the manager left the store.Yes, they are charming while they are selling and do know their merchandise.

9.description: I usually don't spend a lot of money on shoes, but one time I was in a bind (i.e. only pair of sneakers fell apart) and they were the nearest store. The sales people were very helpful (but not pushy) and when I left without buying (to check out the shoes at the opposing North Face store) they were very polite. After comparing shoes, it was a no-brainer. Hanig's shoes were better. I went back and bought the most comfortable shoes I have ever worn.

6.description: My boyfriend and I were shopping around before Christmas while waiting on dinner reservations.  We walked in to this shop and needless to say, I'm wearing new boots.  The staff is extremely attentive, friendly and most of all...knowledgable about what they sale.  Our staff member (I'm the worst and can't remember his name) was phenomenal.   They were a bit busy but still greeted us and asked for specifics on what we were looking for.   Anything I asked or needed help with didn't seem to be a problem at all.  I will return, I'll buy again and recommend to any friend. Three cheers.

18.description: Great comfort shoe store, great selection, great service.I came in to try the Vibram FiveFingers, but am not a convert yet.  I did however get a pair of "barefoot" shoes that don't look like I am wearing some kind of crazy scuba glove on my foot.  Yes, barefoot shoes that are actually cute do exist, and you can find them here!A lot of beautiful, well made shoes in here.  They also seem to focus on comfort, but without sacrificing style.  Prices are on the higher side.  But, I guess you get what you pay for.The staff are friendly, knowledgeable, and super helpful.  I even got a tip for a chocolate-malt-pit-stop on the drive home from Chicago, but we changed routes and did not get to try it out.

10.description: I took my mom here yesterday since she has a hard time finding comfortable shoes. She was a nurse for 40 yrs and developed problems from having a job that required her to mostly be on her feet. It sounded like a perfect store to bring her to, and she was very excited to see the shoe selection. I was very disappointed however by how rudely she was treated by the salesman who was helping her. She would have definitely bought a pair of shoes yesterday, however his rude behavior prevented that. I even overheard him say to another salesman that my mom was being a "pain in the ass". That is unacceptable and I will not shop here again.

13.description: Oh, toe shoes!  If you are looking for an awesome pair of shoes that just so happen to have separated toes, this is the place!I stopped in here during my visit to Chicago because I wanted to try on the Vibram FiveFingers.  They have an awesome selection of them.  Additionally, the salesmen are all really friendly and interested in helping you find something you love.  I tried on a pretty, ultra-feminine lilac pair and they let me wander around the tower in them to check out how they felt on hard ground since the store is carpeted.  I was smitten with my newfound footgloves.  I couldn't help it.  I had to buy them despite all the funny looks I got from other customers.  After returning to Seattle I decided I wanted another pair for me and a pair for my bf.  I called and they sent them to me the next day which is extra impressive considering the limited supply and how hard they can be to come by out here.

16.description: I bought 3 pairs of Thierry Rabotin shoes 3 months ago at the store on Michigan Ave. One pair developed a defect. I wrote an email to the store, not counting on getting a response, and I not only got a response, they said to send the shoes, and they would repair them or replace them.They replaced them. I am thrilled and will promote and buy more shoes from Hanigs forever!

17.description: Very friendly and helpful staff.  The gentleman who helped my girlfriend and I pick out athletic shoes was very knowledgeable, personable, and not pushy.  He seemed extremely passionate about five-finger shoes- awesome!

15.description: I'm pleased to report that the management at Hanig's has reached out to me to correct their mistake. They showed great humility, empathy, and quick action while addressing my concerns showing me that they are deserving of my business and the business of my fellow Yelpers.

0.description: I am writing this review on behalf of my Mother-In-Law, who doesn't write reviews but wanted to make sure the world knows this place is fantastic.She frequently shops here and will continue to buy shoes, sandals and boots here.The reason for this particular review now, is that a recent purchase put Hanig's and the salesman Walter into a new category of fantastic.This past fall she bought new winter boots.  There were warm  and comfortable and were great for a few weeks, until we had a big snow followed by thawing that proved the boots were not actually waterproof.  It is really hard to tell how well boots will do in Chicago winter, and being waterproof is crucial for keeping feet dry while walking around.  When she went back to the store and told Walter the boots weren't water proof, he was very polite, concerned and attentive.  He helped her return the boots and exchange them for new waterproof winter boots.Few places have so much good stuff in a small store and almost nobody has that kind of service - making a customer whole after a disaster.  This experience really proved how valuable Hanig's and Walter are, and solidified the reason to keep purchasing footwear from here.

5.description: To set the stage, I think I am one of the only women on the planet who truly hates shoe shopping.  Like, I loathe it.  If left to my own devices, I will wear a pair of shoes or snow boots into the ground...and then keep wearing them for an embarrassing amount of time as they fray even further while I hmmmm and haw about having to go shoe shopping for a replacement.  I am a creature of habit.If you guys hadn't noticed, Chicago has been extremely snowy this winter...and my three-year-old "professional" work attire snow boots were so terribly busted that they were leaking.  So pathetic.  And then I broke the zipper after having one last (triumphantly stubborn) fight to get them on one morning.  After a rave review of this place by my husband (yes, my husband has to MAKE me go buy shoes), I decided I would check it out.  He went with me and said, "Just talk to my dude".  You know, because every good shoe store story starts this way.  Ike did not disappoint.  It was a crazy-busy day, and he took time to figure out what I liked about my old boots and helped me get set up with a new pair (just in time for more snow storms).  Painless.  Perfection.  Ike.I am only being honest that it might be another three years before I stubbornly replace this particular pair of snow boots, but the moral of this 5-star review is that I will go back to Hanig's for other shoe purchases in the meantime.  Anyone who knows me, knows how spectacular this concept is.

11.description: Used to be a customer when Hanig was at the former MIchigan Ave. location. On a recent visit to the Hancock Bldg. store looking for a favorite brand previously purchased at the former location, the saleman answered "OUR customers are looking for shoes at a higher price point than _______." Guess I'm not one of YOUR customers anymore!

8.description: About two months ago, my boyfriend and I stopped in to get him a pair of Ecco shoes. They're pricey, but comfortable & professional for him. The sales staff we talked to were really polite, professional, and knowledgeable. They seemed to take the customer service side of their job very seriously, unlike other retail shops that have similarly priced products, but absentminded sales staff. We took their suggestions, but found the same brand and style for $60 cheaper online.

3.description: My family knows I'm always looking for the next really comfortable, yet hopefully cute pair of shoes.  There are actually stories about my shoe shopping.  That admitted, I found a shoe store that I loved, in Chicago.  It had brands that I had never tried before.  Specific new find~ Fly London!  I admit i'm on the short side, yet I have trouble balancing on heels.  Problem solved!  Platforms!  Not really crazy, but a 2 1/2 inch heel made wearable thanks to a 1 inch platform.I bought one pair while we were in Chicago and then ordered another pair in a color they were out of stock in.  Nice bonus, free shipping.  When I came home i wanted to see if I could find this brand nearer to me. Yep, Nordstrom had the brand.  However, I saved around $18 a pair buying them at Hanigs and having them shipped.  I'm thinking I have a plan for future purchases at Hanigs!Sales staff was very helpful and knew their shoes!!!

14.description: Located in the lobby of the Hancock Center near the North Face store entrance (and off the Delaware street building entrance).Reasonable selection given their very small location and market.Good sales people, friendly, helpful, no pressure, etc. Fair prices.No complaints. 4 stars.

4.description: Hanig's Shoe store out of the Chicago area is fabulous!!  I have ordered two pairs of shoes from them and the customer service is the best I have experienced.  One pair of shoes cost $40 less than the identical  pair in a store in the DC area and the other was the lowest sale price on the web as well as stores - and there is MORE  - since I live in another of state there is no sales tax (saving an additional 10%) and no shipping charge.  Both  came quickly and in perfect condition. The shoes carried at  Hanig's are from the best lines for comfort, style, and qualify and I am grateful I found such a good source to satisfy my shoe needs.  I promise that you will join me in the praise after your first order.  You can not beat the qualify and service.at Hanig's.  Always check Hanig's online or in person before buying anywhere else.A very satisfied customer

58.description: I loved the Frida Kahlo exhibit and was so inspired by everything in it. I am so glad we stopped by. We spent hours interpreting different art pieces and were filled to the brim with wonder and inspiration by the time we left. Illinois residents have free admission every Tuesday, and also if you are in the military, you have free admission anytime!

56.description: Really, really, really, really disappointing.I love a museum. I even love a sparse museum that showcases a few remarkable pieces. This museum, at least during my recent visit, showcased one great Frida Kahlo piece and one Frida-influenced piece (in the temporary exhibit), and then 5 other really not good pieces (in the permanent gallery). Mobiles are fine, but one mediocre mobile?Mock-finger painting art can be fine too, but this camp-murdery-styled finger painting was just not moving.And the junk piles... yeah, no.The giftshop is really the only reason to visit this place - I swear. Maybe my visit was a fluke, maybe I wasn't in the right mood... I don't know, but I did not love this.

29.description: Came to see David Bowie Is, first time visit. Cool place, but not much going on outside of David Bowie for me. The other exhibits were no where near as interesting as the gift shop imho. As for Mr Bowie, pretty cool to be able to make money and not even be there, just your stuff. You have to hand it to the guy. The exhibit itself was good but not great. It was really more an exhibit of David's outfits, saw just about all the noteworthy ones over the years. This is closing weekend, I waited too long and had to deal with the rush. My advice to you if you intend to go still, pre-purchase tickets are sold out but you can get some walk ups the morning off. Come early and be prepared to wait in the cold for at least an hour. Know that members get entrance and first dibs before you will.If you do get in, this is the most helpful piece of advice I can give you - go immediately to the end of the exhibit and work your way backwards to the front. This will enable you to dodge the masses and actually get to see most of the exhibit without competing for the same as the rest of the mob. That was my take away after going through, that I wish I had done that to start. They say to alot an hour and a half but if you read everything, I'm thinking it is closer to two hours. Tip - if you drive, I recommend using spothero app to save $ on parking. I have used it three times so far and it's solid. If you decide to imbibe, they serve alcohol in the cafe on the 2nd floor. Enjoy!

42.description: I don't remember the first time I was dragged to the MCA as a child, nor do I recall when it stopped being a chore and became a place I felt truly at peace, as it is now for me.True, when you have the Art Institute down the street, the MCA will always be a bridesmaid, never a bride - and while the works shown are often challenging/off-putting, it's still not quite the bastard step-child museum that some naysayers would have you believe. They do have a solid collection of post-war minimalist, surrealist, conceptual works - and the blockbuster shows they put on are generally worth the trip, regardless of what you think of the artist/s featured....thought part of me still wishes that I could un-see the Koons retrospective of 2008 as I wasn't curious what his penis looked like before the show, and am certainly no less intrigued now....but it's contemporary art. There will always be things that don't particularly resonate.Nevertheless, the MCA  fairly consistently offers well-curated and interesting shows, performances, talks that continue to make me cast off my sweatpants when I'm home visiting my folks, and brave the crowds and the horrid parking garage to see whatever they are putting on.If you can get there before Jan 4th, 2015, go to the "David Bowie Is" show, even if you think that Space Oddity is a disaster of a song and you've never really been into a man wearing makeup and platform shoes, just GO. I knew little abt Bowie going in, and the show does an amazing job of being educational and mesmerizing - evidenced by the fact that my date was my 86y grandmother, who had already seen the show once and wanted to go back. It takes abt 2-3h to see the whole thing - well worth taking the time getting lost in how crazy amazing his mind is.After spending a few hours on your feet, if you get peckish, the food at their Puck Cafe is pricey but not shabby - and if you're visiting during one of our 12 days of summer, sit on the patio overlooking the sculpture garden.Museum logistics: admission for non-members is $25 for all access, $7 just to see the regular collection, $15 for students, and $10 for kids 7-12y.Overall, if you're in Chicago - visiting or a resident - the MCA should be on your list of things to do - and if you want a Friday night activity that's not just watching the Bears at a bar, come to their First Friday events for the people watching and mingling.

23.description: ZERO STARS.  NONE.   Worst art museum..wait, worst museum EVER.  Took my son and paid the reduced fee of $7 apiece.  What a waste.  $14 would have been better spent on a few happy meals at McDonalds (which I detest).  I haven't been to the MCA since it was located on Ontario Street and back then, they had a nice selection of inspiring art.  This location is a four floor joke. Put it this way, if all the art at the MCA were on one floor it would take all but about 12 minutes to see everything.  That's not an exaggeration.  Instead, they have four floors here,  which when you leave each floor you'll say to yourself,  okay..maybe there's better content on the next floor.  Nope...never happens.  When you get to the fourth floor you sadly realize that the best part of this museum, by far, is the gift shop and the goldfish pond on the ground floor.   Third place would be for the clean bathroom, which had better art (none) than the museum.Let me get to the art though..as that's what people visit for.  The art here is an unimaginative collection of garbage.  I know the perception of good art differs for us all but the material here would maybe appeal to a hundredth of 1%.  I've been a long time fan of all art, specifically contemporary art, and say with all truthfulness that the art offered here is pathetic (save the Calder pieces).   Especially for a museum with as much financial backing as this one.Look.. If you want to see good art or even contemporary art, do yourself a favor and visit either the Art Institute of Chicago or the Milwaukee Art Museum.  Both are worth the price of admission and have a great deal to offer.  The MCA is a waste of space with a really sad collection of trash (again, save the Calder's).   What an embarrassment to the great city of Chicago.

47.description: Love the MCA in Chicago, great location in downtown Chicago, staff is always friendly, quick check in, 4 floors of always the coolest contemporary artists around the world and love their gift shop, some of the coolest wearable art around.I loved the Bowie Is exhibit, I was totally immersed in the world of Bowie for two hours, if you're a David Bowie fan you must check out this exhibit, the only stop in the US and you have until 1/4/15

8.description: Like a summer blizzard, horror may suddenly land and kill you, your friend or your family. Doris Salcedo's first retrospective exhibition shows that the greatest test of Earth is to bear loss due to political violence without losing heart. In Bogata, the artist's hometown, you do not see the river of mourning because people long lost the ability to cry. From Salcedo's perspective, the fear of death leads to the fear of life, ultimately leading to gang violence. In memory of lost lives, she created Plegaria Muda '08-10 - 2 hand-crafted tables, which approximate the size and shape of coffins. In order to place the life of the dead who were massacred in banana plantations in the memory of the living, the artist created Untitled Works '89-90, white cotton shirts impaled by steel rebar. Here, the boundaries which divide Life from Death are vague, as the standard dress of workers is no different from the funeral dress for the dead.For the artist, Colombians only deepen the wound of the society when they neglect to mourn. Thus, Salcedo built Disremembered '14, raw silk shirt that incorporates 12,000 needles. By failing to cry, people choose to deny their humanity. No one saves us but ourselves. To dream of the future, let yourself mourn, remember and learn from the dead. As Salcedo says, we ourselves must walk the path.

31.description: The 'David Bowie is' exhibit is dense with information, notes, his art, and costumes. I stopped and stared longest at the Pierrot costume (where I got a lump in my throat) from the Ashes to Ashes video. Most of his famous costumes are included. The depth of his artistry is breathtaking, from the letters to the songwriting to the set design to the music. It's quite amazing and features headsets which sense where you are and give audio interviews and musical accompaniment to the many videos. The Chicago stop at the MCA is the only one in North America and ends January 4.

34.description: I really liked coming to 1st Fridays here. Laying in the grass at the MCA back yard, listening to jazz and having a glass of wine...cool stuff! This also allows you to check out some of the exhibits. All FOR FREE! I also planned a visit with a large group of college students. They enjoyed themselves. Check out 1st Friday during the summer months!

16.description: I'm conflicted on writing this review because there are really two things to review: the museum itself and the David Bowie exhibit I saw. I have only visited here once for the David Bowie exhibit, but I'll try to  review the whole museum as fairly as I can. David Bowie exhibit: 5 stars. I learned a LOT about Davie Bowie. The whole exhibit was extremely well put-together. A lot of thought clearly went into it from the outfits tot he video clips, etc. At first, I was a bit taken aback that it cost a whopping $25 per person to see this exhibit, but I held out judgment before seeing the exhibit. It was really worth every penny. We got our money's worth. I especially enjoyed that everyone got an audio guide with further information. The time when everyone enters the exhibit is regulated, but I liked that they didn't regulate how much time we had in the exhibit. We took our sweet time, listening to the entire audio guide and reading everything we could find.The rest of MCA: 2 stars. I have nothing against the museum. I just think I'm not a big contemporary art guy. I have trouble understanding and appreciating modern art like this. We walked through the whole museum and there weren't any pieces that really stood out to me. Maybe I'm a common philistine, but I just couldn't be convinced there was value in the painting with a splotch of paint on it that my young cousin could have created. It also didn't help that the majority of the art either was not titled or did not have a description. C'mon, give me somethin', here. Gift shop: 4 stars. There were a ton of really creative, inventive, fun items. We enjoyed this more than the actual museum, to be honest. I knocked off a star because a lot of the items were too expensive. It was really fun to check out this gift shop, though.Overall, I wasn't impressed by the museum itself, but the exhibit knocked me away. I would not return just for the "regularly schedule programming," but I would certainly come back for an exhibit as exciting as David Bowie Is. Note: There's a free coat check. Score.

13.description: Review is for the David Bowie exhibit. I was never a huge fan but, did like some of his stuff so I didn't really understand him and what he was trying to do at the time. The exhibit, which is both interesting and innovative provides much greater clarity into the man, his music, mission, fashion and the unique way in which he made it to the pinnacle of the music world.  I am more of a fan know that I understand his journey and the courage it took to be different.The exhibit unfolds his life story with writings, photos, videos, painting and of course music. A sensor in your headset changes the music in conjunction to where you are standing in a given room and what video you are watching.  His costumes, designed by some of the premier fashions designers on the planet at the time are fabulous.Just before you leave, there is a large 360 degree room on your right that you should linger in for a while and just take in the sights and sounds.

11.description: I love to check out modern art museums when visiting different cities.  I have to say that the Chicago Museum of Contemporary Art does not house a great deal of art for its size, I would have expected more but it was still worth a visit.  Since the friend I was visiting with is in the military, we were able to take advantage of his discount.  The employees were also not only knowledgable but very helpful and friendly.

39.description: Review is for the David Bowie exhibit. I was never a huge fan but, did like some of his stuff so I didn't really understand him and what he was trying to do at the time. The exhibit, which is both interesting and innovative provides much greater clarity into the man, his music, mission, fashion and the unique way in which he made it to the pinnacle of the music world.  I am more of a fan know that I understand his journey and the courage it took to be different.The exhibit unfolds his life story with writings, photos, videos, painting and of course music. A sensor in your headset changes the music in conjunction to where you are standing in a given room and what video you are watching.  His costumes, designed by some of the premier fashions designers on the planet at the time are fabulous.Just before you leave, there is a large 360 degree room on your right that you should linger in for a while and just take in the sights and sounds.

37.description: The Bowie exhibit was the reason I came to Chicago for the weekend. Nice museum, great exhibit.

0.description: I totally don't consider myself to be that artistic, so take this review with a grain of salt. I like coming to the MCA because they have a lot of events. Whether it's Jazz on the terrace or a new modern exhibit...MCA is always at the cutting edge of Art. I also used to go here for first Friday events back in my 20's...lol. I like that they encourage Illinois residents to come by making the admission free on Tuesdays. I went this pass Tuesday to enjoy Museum week. Some of the art work I just didn't understand, but some of it was thought provoking as I toured the Freedom Principle exhibit. For residences or tourists it's a great place to come and explore contemporary art.

38.description: Contemporary art was my FAVORITE subject that I ever studied, no matter which school, grade, or class I was in... hands down. I LOVED learning about the incredibly thought-provoking and deep/hidden messages behind each and every art piece. It made me feel like there were others in the world who thought like me, and I loved that feeling! I have a membership for this year, and I'm not sure if it's my fault (for lack of research) or the museum's for their exhibits not having enough, or sometimes any information, about most of their pieces. I would love nothing more than to learn about the ideas behind these mysterious yet interesting works. I know you can probably rent some head-phones for the day or take a tour with a knowledgeable guide, but I'd love to read about the art off a plaque with detailed information. Otherwise, I'll be in the dark until then.

51.description: David Bowie Is exhibit is worth the visit. Buy tickets in advance for your assigned date and time. The exhibit has a very extensive collection and Is interactive with a GPS locator for your headphones (included with your admission ticket) which automatically targets the area you are in and feeds the music or explanation to your headphones. They limit the amount of people that enter on the hour and I found it very manageable even on opening weekend.  Currently the other exhibits in the museum were a complete snooze .... Which I was disappoint in because I am a fan and planned extra time to see the rest of the exhibits. But currently the only attraction worthy in my opinion is the Bowie exhibit. If you want a large selection and hours an hours of art intensity check out the Art Institute.

27.description: Made our way through the windy WINDY streets to the MCA and it was well worth but maybe a little bit sparse.  My husband was super excited for the Bowie exhibit so we did that first.  There were some really cool videos and paraphernalia from back in the day.  The coolest part was seeing the outfits.  Man, David Bowie was/is a Size 0.  He is one tiny dude.  Didn't realize that he was like the beginning of 'branding' as a musician.  Very interesting.I kind of cruised through this part, excited for the museum and was a little disappointed.  Not a ton otherwise but as I have said for other museums (the Kemper, etc) I'm a fan of these smaller museums which are less overwhelming for a Saturday morning blast of culture.

32.description: So sad, randomly made a visit here during my stay to discover an awesome Bowie exhibit. Sadly it was $25 each and a last minute thing at an end of a trip so financially I just couldn't do it. But we did get general admission at $7 each (two of us) to explore the rest of the museum. There was a great Body Doubles exhibit on the main floor that had some really great sculpture pieces. It was definitely my favorite exhibit going on.

54.description: This museum was very disappointing. My mom and I went, primarily to see the "Frida Kahlo" exhibit. To call this exhibit a Frida exhibit is deceiving, as there were only 2, very small pieces of work by her. The other pieces in the exhibit were by other artist after her time. My mom, being a Frida enthusiast was especially disappointed, as she has visited numerous Frida exhibits and stated this was by far the worst one. The rest of the museum was sparse, with limited pieces. Because the David Bowie exhibit is coming soon, this whole section is currently not being utilized (about 1/4 of the museum). There was so little to see we were in and out pretty quickly. The museum was pretty empty, although there was tons of security. One security guard actually told us to be ware because the security on the 4th floor carried guns. Seemed a little intense, especially based on the fact that there were about 15 people in the entire museum.

48.description: BOWIE ISFANTASTIC!!!!!!! Right around the corner from Mile North Hotel. Best stay ever!!!

44.description: David Bowie exhibit-  let me say I did not purchase his albums back in the day.  so maybe a distant fan.  however, this exhibit was done so well, you can get to know what a wonderful artist he was!  the head set senses your location and just does its thing, you do not have to worry about pressing display buttons.  the pieces they had were truly impressive, the clothing pieces to his music scribbles.  throughout there were video pieces too, that make you pause to listen.  The last room with the wall screen and outfits behind it was my favorite, i could sit there and listen all day.  amazing amazing. I went first thing in the morning on a Thursday, no crowd, so you can go right up displays and read the placard.  on the 4th floor, finish a room, before heading to another room, no photography of any kind :((

24.description: As a photographer and installation artist, I definitely recommend this museum. They always have great contemporary exhibits, bring in incredible talent for lectures and other events, and work collaboratively with the Art Institute on occasion. The staff is extremely friendly and even allowed me to place a few postcards for my own exhibit at their front desk for guests to grab. One of my favorite perks is that they have a room dedicated to local talent - which is super rare. I've had some friends invited to show their work in that space & both exhibits came out very well. It's smaller than the Art Institute so you can get through everything in an afternoon. The location is extremely convenient, and they have a small parking facility as well as nearby street parking. I highly recommend this venue!

7.description: This was awesome. Before you say, well, "I could make that!" first ask yourself, Why didn't you? What where the circumstances in the artist's life that led to this expression? What does it say about society and world? While Rock n' Roll no longer exists to stick it to the man, as it is dead, or worse, in collaboration with "The Man", Modern Art represents the last bastion of that spirit.

49.description: OK this is officially one of my favorite museums!It helps that my aunt has a membership so I get to go for free every time I am in Chicago :)

40.description: The museum is great, from the massive Yinka Shonibare sculptures outside to the wonderful David Bowie exhibition currently show now until January 4th. I would definitely recommend the Bowie exhibit to anyone who is a fan. His personal archive is amazing and includes original artwork, handwritten notes, costumes etc. There is a complementary coat room for your bags and jackets and they validate parking if you decide to drive and park in the garage. Although, the validated parking is 'discounted' i would recommend taking the CTA or walking because it was still $29 for about two hours!

53.description: The 4th-floor David Bowie exhibit was well done & reminded me a little of an Andy Warhol touring exhibit about rock n' roll that did the modern art museum rounds a couple years ago. The rest of the museum is a pleasant space, but a sparse collection. I guess I have artistic differences over the Frida Kahlo "exhibit." I found myself enjoying the building & its gathering places, like the outdoor cafe and the front entry steps, more than the permanent collection. FYI extremely convenient parking is available in a parking garage right beside the museum.

30.description: Visited the David Bowie exhibit the day after Christmas.  What a treat!  The other exhibits weren't as interesting but the museum is beautiful, the staff is so helpful and the price of admission was surprisingly reasonable!

46.description: We went to see David Bowie Is at the MCA.  Very cool exhibit, friendly staff.  Browsed the other art afterwards.  A good place to spend a few hours!

1.description: Came the first weekend of the month, so admissions was taken care of thanks to BoA card. Ticketing was a breeze and the museum was a bore. Everything was a temporary exhibit and not very insightful and followed a similar pop culture coming of age theme. I also walked into one exhibit and was stopped by a staff member because my crossbody bag was situated behind at the moment I was leaning down reading details on the art piece--"bag must be in front." ?!?! Several other crossbody bag carriers had their bags situated behind throughout the exhibit...talk to them as they wander and not to someone reading. If it wasn't for BoA museum weekend, I'd been even more disappointed.Lastly, I was partially here to scout out space for a possible event. Pass. It was quite bland and no good views, not to mention unwelcoming staff.

55.description: If you're coming here for a vast collection of canonical modern art, forget it.  If that's what you want, the Modern Wing at the Art Institute slays the MCA in terms of its permanent collection.  This is a very small museum -  the entire thing can be taken in in under 2 hours. Come to the MCA for funky hidden gems, and just plain weird stuff - like the recent Isa Genzken retrospective. I'm really looking forward to the David Bowie exhibit opening soon. To me, this is the little museum that could. And if you have kids, the cafe here is great. Lots of tables, nice places to sit and have a drink and take a rest from sight seeing.

9.description: Came to see David Bowie Is, first time visit. Cool place, but not much going on outside of David Bowie for me. The other exhibits were no where near as interesting as the gift shop imho. As for Mr Bowie, pretty cool to be able to make money and not even be there, just your stuff. You have to hand it to the guy. The exhibit itself was good but not great. It was really more an exhibit of David's outfits, saw just about all the noteworthy ones over the years. This is closing weekend, I waited too long and had to deal with the rush. My advice to you if you intend to go still, pre-purchase tickets are sold out but you can get some walk ups the morning off. Come early and be prepared to wait in the cold for at least an hour. Know that members get entrance and first dibs before you will.If you do get in, this is the most helpful piece of advice I can give you - go immediately to the end of the exhibit and work your way backwards to the front. This will enable you to dodge the masses and actually get to see most of the exhibit without competing for the same as the rest of the mob. That was my take away after going through, that I wish I had done that to start. They say to alot an hour and a half but if you read everything, I'm thinking it is closer to two hours. Tip - if you drive, I recommend using spothero app to save $ on parking. I have used it three times so far and it's solid. If you decide to imbibe, they serve alcohol in the cafe on the 2nd floor. Enjoy!

26.description: I'm conflicted on writing this review because there are really two things to review: the museum itself and the David Bowie exhibit I saw. I have only visited here once for the David Bowie exhibit, but I'll try to  review the whole museum as fairly as I can. David Bowie exhibit: 5 stars. I learned a LOT about Davie Bowie. The whole exhibit was extremely well put-together. A lot of thought clearly went into it from the outfits tot he video clips, etc. At first, I was a bit taken aback that it cost a whopping $25 per person to see this exhibit, but I held out judgment before seeing the exhibit. It was really worth every penny. We got our money's worth. I especially enjoyed that everyone got an audio guide with further information. The time when everyone enters the exhibit is regulated, but I liked that they didn't regulate how much time we had in the exhibit. We took our sweet time, listening to the entire audio guide and reading everything we could find.The rest of MCA: 2 stars. I have nothing against the museum. I just think I'm not a big contemporary art guy. I have trouble understanding and appreciating modern art like this. We walked through the whole museum and there weren't any pieces that really stood out to me. Maybe I'm a common philistine, but I just couldn't be convinced there was value in the painting with a splotch of paint on it that my young cousin could have created. It also didn't help that the majority of the art either was not titled or did not have a description. C'mon, give me somethin', here. Gift shop: 4 stars. There were a ton of really creative, inventive, fun items. We enjoyed this more than the actual museum, to be honest. I knocked off a star because a lot of the items were too expensive. It was really fun to check out this gift shop, though.Overall, I wasn't impressed by the museum itself, but the exhibit knocked me away. I would not return just for the "regularly schedule programming," but I would certainly come back for an exhibit as exciting as David Bowie Is. Note: There's a free coat check. Score.

25.description: This review is solely based on the David Bowie exhibit. First and foremost, KUDOS to the MCA for being the only museum in the country to host the David Bowie is... exhibit. Overall, I LOVED the exhibit. How could you not? It's based upon the career of a truly fascinating and phenomenal musician. This exhibit was fairly comprehensive. After my visit, I fell in love with David Bowie a hundred times more. Seriously, this man is incredible! The reason I rated it a four was due to the exhibit set-up. I'm not sure if this was the museums responsibility or if the exhibit was set up by an outside company. I appreciate their attempt at keeping the flow of traffic consistent and moving, but I felt as if the traffic flow, at times, was a  hindrance because it did not go along with the exhibits. Additionally, it interfered with the audio component. I heard the audio for  part of the exhibit that was on the other side of the room that I hadn't reached, yet. It was uber confusing and a little frustrated. As much as I love "Space Oddity" I didn't want to hear it 10 times in a row. Despite those hiccups at the start of the exhibit things improved. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit ot the pop up shop. Awesome selection of books, music, etc and reasonably priced for a museum.  My friends and I spent hours there and still didn't want to leave. It was AMAZING!

12.description: When did the architecture of art museums start to get better than the contemporaneous art?  I guess it must have been between 1967 and 1976 -- the period when the MCA was built and when Mark Rothko and Alexander Calder died.  The building is really nice -- a compact but lovely and modern space, with a particularly nice cafe patio (one of the only places downtown I can think of where you can order food and sit outside while still getting a peek of the lake) and a beautiful staircase with corners and roundnesses and several other nice touches.  But the art is mostly not my cup of tea -- and in small portions, too.  There were a few nice Calder mobiles from the permanent collection, but they were displayed in stifling air and indirectly lit so you could see neither movement nor shadows.  The more adventurous stuff was educational but not exactly edifying.  At just a few dollars for a faculty admission it would be worth it just to sit in the building for a spell.  And the gift store is inspired too.  But I wouldn't bother with most of the art.

59.description: I went last night for Tuesdays on the terrace. It was fun. You can bring a chair and watch while the band plays or you can bring a blanket and sit on the lawn. I found a good parking on spot hero. I had some wine from the bar it wasn't a good white wine. I also had a veggie burger and salt chips that was very good. The music was great. They do tell you that you can't bring outside drinks or food but I saw a lot of people with their own food. Warning it's a lot of kids there. It wouldn't be a big deal if parents would make them play in the square near the rocks. This one mommy circle sat and talked to each other while their kids were running around doing cart wheels. It's not a large lawn for all that. You also can see the exhibits . Great event

21.description: Couldn't beat FREE admission for military folks. It's usually $12 regular admission. If you're a senior or student, then it's $7.When they say contemporary art...it's pretty contemporary with a lot of 2014 and 2015 stuff hanging around. Mostly local artists and their pieces were out on display.A few notables such as Frida Kahlo and some of her work is here and a few other Mexican artists around the same time period. But they change out their stuff often, so the Frida exhibhit may not be there by the time you read this review.Although there are 4 stories of art, I saw the whole thing in about 35 minutes...and I wasn't trying to rush it either, so your visit here will be relatively quick.Photography is allowed but no flash.

17.description: So sad, randomly made a visit here during my stay to discover an awesome Bowie exhibit. Sadly it was $25 each and a last minute thing at an end of a trip so financially I just couldn't do it. But we did get general admission at $7 each (two of us) to explore the rest of the museum. There was a great Body Doubles exhibit on the main floor that had some really great sculpture pieces. It was definitely my favorite exhibit going on.

10.description: Um... so, I think we may have come during an off period? There were some cool Alexander Calder mobiles that were beautiful, and there were some cool experiential art (like a hot air balloon you got to walk inside) but other than those things it was pretty disappointing. They had a huge portion of the first floor dedicated to the showing of these documentaries that my friends and I sat through, and even after reading the plaques on the wall I definitely did not "get" what they were trying to get across. I could have made up a bunch of fancy sounding junk (finally! a use for my BA in English!) but it just wasn't worth the effort. We all left disappointed.The staff was nice though, and if you're into super modern art that doesn't really make sense but gives you the opportunity to say a bunch of BS to sound smart - this is the place for you.

5.description: I had been dying to visit MOCA since I moved to Chicago early June. I finally got the chance to on a Tuesday when I was not working. Behold an amazing surprise when I found out Chicago residents get free admission on Tuesdays!! I was so elated.I particular enjoyed the Keren Cytter exhibit the most. It was unlike any exhibit I have ever seen before because she used lots of videography for her art - on top of her paintings. This was the first contemporary art museum I have visited and I must admit that prior to my visit, I had no clear idea of what contemporary meant in terms of art. MOCA does a great job of bringing in truly 100% unique and unusual exhibits to Chicago. It takes some critical thinking and observation to wrap your head around some of these concepts. I will return.

3.description: Chicago has many impressive, world-class museums.  When you're bored of museums, you can take architecture tours and cruises.  When you're bored of that, you can walk the streets, soak in the culture of the neighborhoods, and look for the various plaques, historical markers, and public sculptures that are hidden in plain sight.When you're bored of that, I suppose you can check out the MCA.  I finally went after 7 years of living in the city just to cross it off the list.  It's what I expected; junk and splotches that occasionally, accidentally become something aesthetically pleasing.  The building itself is pretty, and centrally-located.  So if you're in the area, and you want some cheap laughs for an hour or two, stop by.

35.description: I should preface this review by saying it's based solely on the David Bowie IS exhibit.I saw the Bowie exhibit today at the MCA. There is SO much to take in. I really enjoyed it, but it does leave you a bit exhausted after experiencing visual overload from the multitudes of videos, interviews and costumes he's accrued over the years. I'm not complaining, mind you...that's to be expected, given his long career and constant self-reinventing. I found the hand written lyrics to some of my favorite songs being right in front of me particularly cool and, of course, the incredibly imaginative/creative stage attire left me with a new appreciation for the designers, themselves. The only sad part was noticing how many people in "the business" had very short lives. I don't want to jump to conclusions as to why...that doesn't matter. But they certainly left their mark during the short time they had by giving us some incredibly beautiful and strange creations, that's for sure.I don't think you have to be an absolute David Bowie Fanatic to enjoy this show, necessarily...but if you're a fan of music in general, I think you'll find it's worth the $25 admission fee.

19.description: Expecting much and receiving little. It appears the only place to look at the permanent display is in the gift shop. It appears 75% of museum is temporary collections 20% is under construction and 5% is what I came to see. The entire 4th floor consists of entertainment for elementary children including a wall of their thoughts on art. This museum has so much to display and it is a shame they choose to hide it all away.

28.description: If I could give it no stars I might have done it. There's a few good pieces & exhibits here & there but overall I really don't think much of it should be considered art. To me art is something that takes mastery of a set of skills to create a work(s) for example the Classics with their sculptures so real that you could think there's a person doused in white standing still before you. However, many of the things here could be done by untrained children. I know many of you may disagree with me & I respect your opinions just as I hope you respect mine for we all have the right to have opinions of our own.

45.description: I was there on a Sunday for the David Bowie exhibit and it was a full house, the exhibit itself is absolutely vast and incredible, i'm a Bowie fan but went with my brother who really wasn't one before visiting the exhibit and he really enjoyed it as well. The interactive headphones with GPS that targets your location feeds you great info and amazing music. It is kid friendly and i was surprised to see many well behaved little ones walking around with their cool parents. Now, my only complain is the number of people per group, a different group enters the exhibit every 30 minutes and as the amount of people walking around increases (and because of the lack of an actual guide) it tends to get sort of unorganized and quite crowded..

33.description: This is a smaller but well-curated chicago art museum. It is in a plain building in a busy part of town. They have an attached garage and will provide a parking discount if you park there. The museum is laid out over 4 floors. The first floor has the two largest galleries. The second and third floors have smaller spaces. The fourth floor has a large gallery space that is currently being used for the David Bowie exhibit. Overall we had a nice experience here. Staff is very helpful and interior is clean and bright. There were exhibits that I greatly enjoyed, and also some that were really not to my taste. But hey, that's modern art for you. If you are planning to go to the Bowie exhibit then I would recommend going on a weekday as it was very crowded on a Saturday. If possible I would also recommend NOT eating here- it was absolutely terrible. Plan your visit to have lunch before or after your experience at somewhere better. I feel that a normal visitor could see all of the exhibits in about half a day.

43.description: I also went to the "David Bowie is..." exhibit while I was in Chicago the other weekend.  I enjoyed the exhibit very much, and I mostly know David Bowie from Ziggy Stardust and 'Labyrinth,' one of my favorite movies.  So, yup.  I think that particular exhibit lasts until January, but don't quote me, go to their website, mkay.  I liked the fiat that was hanging from the wall too.  ps.  You should also eat at the Wolfgang Puck restaurant/museum cafe.  It was yummy.  I had this corn chowder with a crab fritter in it, and a fish taco. Me gusta seafood.  You can see the lake, just barely, from the outdoor patio.  p.p.s You might get more from your money if you go to the Art Institute of Chicago, but I'd been there before and I like to go new places even though I didn't see everything when I had visited the Art Institute (plus, there are always new exhibits to see).  p.p.p.s  I know, this is getting ridiculous, right?  But, you can't go to a big city and not go to a museum.  It just isn't done. =)  In my world, anyways. Love!

2.description: I really wanted to like this place. That didn't happen.First time my parents came to visit Chicago we went to this museum after hearing some good critiques and expected to have a mind blowing experience. We ended up having a mind blowing experience... out of boredom. The museum was not as impressive as I thought it would be and the exhibitions were pretty exhausting. I kind of waited for it to end. I thought it was just me who is not culturally developed enough to enjoy modern art, but soon came to realize that my mom was half asleep and my husband kept searching for the exit. Eventually even my dad, who was the most enthusiastic about modern art, admitted he was disappointed.I recommend coming here only if you're truly passionate about modern art. Otherwise, there are better places in Chicago to visit.

18.description: This review is solely based on the David Bowie exhibit. First and foremost, KUDOS to the MCA for being the only museum in the country to host the David Bowie is... exhibit. Overall, I LOVED the exhibit. How could you not? It's based upon the career of a truly fascinating and phenomenal musician. This exhibit was fairly comprehensive. After my visit, I fell in love with David Bowie a hundred times more. Seriously, this man is incredible! The reason I rated it a four was due to the exhibit set-up. I'm not sure if this was the museums responsibility or if the exhibit was set up by an outside company. I appreciate their attempt at keeping the flow of traffic consistent and moving, but I felt as if the traffic flow, at times, was a  hindrance because it did not go along with the exhibits. Additionally, it interfered with the audio component. I heard the audio for  part of the exhibit that was on the other side of the room that I hadn't reached, yet. It was uber confusing and a little frustrated. As much as I love "Space Oddity" I didn't want to hear it 10 times in a row. Despite those hiccups at the start of the exhibit things improved. I thoroughly enjoyed my visit ot the pop up shop. Awesome selection of books, music, etc and reasonably priced for a museum.  My friends and I spent hours there and still didn't want to leave. It was AMAZING!

41.description: RIP my hero. =-(We were both super grumpy and only got 4 hours of sleep before we came down here from ohare. I had gotten tickets and planned this part of the trip a month in advance as a brief stopover on my way home from my original seattle trip just to see the BOWIE exhibit.  We barely had time to scarp down a scooby snack before having to get there at the ticketed time of 1pm. I was kicking myself...why did I not buy tickets for later in the day???We got here on sunday a little before 1pm and got our tickets at will call. No lines at ticketing or will call. The lines waiting to get in were manageable to nonexistent ...breezed through everything (maybe we avoided it by being a little late).. and I got in and geeked out to my idol.OMG this exhibit is a super dorky bowie fan's dream come true.His clothes, his handwritten song lyrics to many of his greatest hits....drool. It was a bit more crowded inside.... You have to line up to get in and at first people would stand around looking at his most iconic stuff giving the illusion that there is a line but I soon realized there was no line...the reality is that some stuff enjoyed less traffic than others so it was better sometimes to go and look at that stuff first and maybe come back later for the stuff that people initially crowded around. My jet lag and hunger faded away within the first 10 mins. I got lost in the stuff and lost track of my husband and the crowds and didn't care. He mostly enjoyed people watching. I  dropped 160 bucks at the gift shop on the paperback exhibit book and some tees. Glad I did because the book was more expensive if you tried to get it online later.I obsessively know all his stuff in the 70's through to tin machine; the exhibit concentrated on the 70's stuff which I ate up...less emphasis on his 80's and 90's stuff (maybe 1 room toward the end) which were of little interest to me. I grew up in the 80's when it was not cool to like his darker 70's stuff. Bowie's music has been  the soundtrack to many memories of my childhood so having his songs wane back and forth as you went from exhibit to exhibit was super super cool.The ending was really nice..it's the bowie concert experience. I loved the David Live album and "Sweet thing" is one of my favorite songs so seeing that outfit at the end and hearing that song really did it for me.I stayed for 3 hours and had the time of my life. I wasn't going to see the stuff again so I did doubleback and re-see some of the stuff I thought were esp cool. I'm glad the guards didn't frown upon that because I did come a long way as I'm sure others.  If I lived closer, I'd go again.
